IN FIRST GAME AT HOMEWOOD FIELD
Mountaineers Unable to Score Against Black and Blue
Gridders in Opening Contest

the Mt. St. Mary's gridders home last Saturday at the tail end of a
21-0 score. The Mountaineers were outclassed from the beginning of
the game although they threatened the local squad on several occasions in the second half. The Black and Blue displayed but little of
the promise shown last week against Princeton due, perhaps, to the

Baltimore, Md., OCTOBER 16, 1923

1924 JUNE WEEK
1923 June Week, the report of which is printed in this issue of
The News-Letter, was an undisputed success, financially and otherwise. No previous event or series of events has ever given the University as much advertising throughout the city or has brought into
play as much college spirit as did the delightful affairs which culminated in the never-to-be-forgotten Senior Ball at the Hotel Betvedere. Our only misgiving is that it will be extremely difficult for
other June Weeks to equal the one of 1923.
As Thomas M. Landy, Chairman of 1923 June Week Committee,
intimates, there were times last spring when financial success received a faint hope, a vague dream. Hopkins had never seen a June
Week before and skeptics and conservatives needed much persuasion
before they decided to co-operate. Indefatigable work by certain
students of the University, however, succeeded in bringing about the
success, of which all upper classmen are not only cognizant, but arc
proud.
The task of the 1924 Committee should not be as difficult. The
pioneers have gone ahead and laid low the worst enemies—skepticism and doubt---and it should not be difficult to dispose of tickets.
There is', however, much to be accomplished if the affairs next June
are to equal in brilliance and charm the festivities of 1923. It is essential that the Committee begin functioning immediately.

"GOOD MORNING"
At a recent meeting of the Sigma Chi Beta Society a "cheery good
morning" was approved as "the best possible means of promoting
a more friendly attitude among the students at Homewood." For
the past several years various organizations on the campus have
made desultory attempts to install the "Hello" system. These attempts however, invariably died from lack of nourishment and it was
nothing unusual for Hopkins men to pass each other without a sign
of recognition.
With the advent of the Freshman regulation making it compulsory for first-year men to speak to all upper classmen, conditions
have begun to improve. The upper classes, recognizing the betterment of spirit that is being obtained, are returning the Freshmen's
greetings and are beginning to adopt the habit themselves.
Hopkins is handicapped in many ways because of the fact that it
is a "small college." It should, therefore, utilize all advantages issuing from this condition. The size of the student body at Homewood makes it possible for every Hopkins man to recognize every
other Hopkins man. A state of affairs which does not exist at larger
universities.
We suggest that the entire student body adopt Sigma Chi Beta's
recommendation of a "cheery good morning."

Junior and Senior Engineering Students
Find Duplicates of "Devil's Delights" at Steel Plant

An excellent sample of the conditions in the life hereafter was afforded a group of junior and senior
engineering students last Friday
afternoon at the Sparrows Point
Steel Plant of the Bethlehem Steel
Corporation. The group, under
the guidance of Prof. Alexander G.
Christie and Associates William
B. Kouwenhoven and Frank W.
Kouwenhoven, of the Mechanical
Engineering Department, was
conducted through the plant as a
part of the course in Materials of
Engineering. In order to obtain
a better view of the various processes, the students had to approach within a few feet of a blast
furnace discharging liquid red-hot
iron; stand on a small bridge a few
feet above rolls pressing red hot
rails; and stand an a small observation tower a few feet from a
ladle dumping several hundred
tons of molten slag. The terrific
heat, the blinding light and deafening crackle caused by these processes combined to form as realistic a hell as anyone could desire.
At one time the effect was heightened by the ghastly glare caused
by the action of an automatic generator cut-out switch.
The inspection party met at
12 o'clock in Machinery Hall,
Homewood on Friday and proceeded to the Sparrows Point
plant on the 12.15 car. The inspection tour covered the coke
ovens, the blast furnaces, the open
hearth furnaces, the rolling mills
and the powerhouse.

FROSH PUT OVER SEASON TICKET CAMPAIGN
The Freshman Class deserves praise for the way they
have handled the football season tickets. Graduate Manager Keyes made the following statements:
"The Season Ticket Sale this year is the best ever had
for football due to co-operation of the Freshman Class. Last
year we employed a publicity man to manage the sale and
netted only nine hundred dollars ($900.00). This year our
present net profit on the sale is one thousand and fifty-one
dollars ($1,051.00) and subscriptions are still coming in.

Baltimore, Md., OCTOBER 16, 1923

1924 JUNE WEEK
1923 June Week, the report of which is printed in this issue of
The News-Letter, was an undisputed success, financially and otherwise. No previous event or series of events has ever given the University as much advertising throughout the city or has brought into
play as much college spirit as did the delightful affairs which culminated in the never-to-be-forgotten Senior Ball at the Hotel Betvedere. Our only misgiving is that it will be extremely difficult for
other June Weeks to equal the one of 1923.
As Thomas M. Landy, Chairman of 1923 June Week Committee,
intimates, there were times last spring when financial success received a faint hope, a vague dream. Hopkins had never seen a June
Week before and skeptics and conservatives needed much persuasion
before they decided to co-operate. Indefatigable work by certain
students of the University, however, succeeded in bringing about the
success, of which all upper classmen are not only cognizant, but arc
proud.
The task of the 1924 Committee should not be as difficult. The
pioneers have gone ahead and laid low the worst enemies—skepticism and doubt---and it should not be difficult to dispose of tickets.
There is', however, much to be accomplished if the affairs next June
are to equal in brilliance and charm the festivities of 1923. It is essential that the Committee begin functioning immediately.

"GOOD MORNING"
At a recent meeting of the Sigma Chi Beta Society a "cheery good
morning" was approved as "the best possible means of promoting
a more friendly attitude among the students at Homewood." For
the past several years various organizations on the campus have
made desultory attempts to install the "Hello" system. These attempts however, invariably died from lack of nourishment and it was
nothing unusual for Hopkins men to pass each other without a sign
of recognition.
With the advent of the Freshman regulation making it compulsory for first-year men to speak to all upper classmen, conditions
have begun to improve. The upper classes, recognizing the betterment of spirit that is being obtained, are returning the Freshmen's
greetings and are beginning to adopt the habit themselves.
Hopkins is handicapped in many ways because of the fact that it
is a "small college." It should, therefore, utilize all advantages issuing from this condition. The size of the student body at Homewood makes it possible for every Hopkins man to recognize every
other Hopkins man. A state of affairs which does not exist at larger
universities.
We suggest that the entire student body adopt Sigma Chi Beta's
recommendation of a "cheery good morning."

Junior and Senior Engineering Students
Find Duplicates of "Devil's Delights" at Steel Plant

An excellent sample of the conditions in the life hereafter was afforded a group of junior and senior
engineering students last Friday
afternoon at the Sparrows Point
Steel Plant of the Bethlehem Steel
Corporation. The group, under
the guidance of Prof. Alexander G.
Christie and Associates William
B. Kouwenhoven and Frank W.
Kouwenhoven, of the Mechanical
Engineering Department, was
conducted through the plant as a
part of the course in Materials of
Engineering. In order to obtain
a better view of the various processes, the students had to approach within a few feet of a blast
furnace discharging liquid red-hot
iron; stand on a small bridge a few
feet above rolls pressing red hot
rails; and stand an a small observation tower a few feet from a
ladle dumping several hundred
tons of molten slag. The terrific
heat, the blinding light and deafening crackle caused by these processes combined to form as realistic a hell as anyone could desire.
At one time the effect was heightened by the ghastly glare caused
by the action of an automatic generator cut-out switch.
The inspection party met at
12 o'clock in Machinery Hall,
Homewood on Friday and proceeded to the Sparrows Point
plant on the 12.15 car. The inspection tour covered the coke
ovens, the blast furnaces, the open
hearth furnaces, the rolling mills
and the powerhouse.

FROSH PUT OVER SEASON TICKET CAMPAIGN
The Freshman Class deserves praise for the way they
have handled the football season tickets. Graduate Manager Keyes made the following statements:
"The Season Ticket Sale this year is the best ever had
for football due to co-operation of the Freshman Class. Last
year we employed a publicity man to manage the sale and
netted only nine hundred dollars ($900.00). This year our
present net profit on the sale is one thousand and fifty-one
dollars ($1,051.00) and subscriptions are still coming in.
